title: Cinema cancels Joker screenings after police discover 'credible threat'

A cinema was forced to cancel screenings of mega movie Joker following what police say was a "credible" threat.

The Californian theatre took the action as the blockbuster opened across America.

The film, starring Joaquin Phoenix as Batman's sadistic nemesis, has hit the headlines because of its levels of violence.

Across the States there have been heightened security fears surrounding its release.

Police in cities including New York and Las Vegas have stepped up patrols at cinemas showing the movie.

Family members of victims of a 2012 mass shooting by a man reportedly identifying himself as Joker have expressed concerns about the film.

(Image: WARNER BROS FILMS)

(Image: ABC7)

On Friday, it emerged a cinema in Huntington Beach, a city south east of Los Angeles, had cancelled two Thursday night showings after police were called.

Their Police Department said it had received reports of a possible threat to the Century Theatre at the Bella Terra shopping centre and were treating it as "credible".

The cinema reopened on Friday, police said. They declined to provide details of the threat.

Joker is directed by Todd Phillips and acts as an origins story for Joker. Set in 1981, it follows failed stand-up comedian Arthur Fleck, who turns to a life of crime in Gotham City.

(Image: Warner Bros)

(Image: Warner Bros)

Warner Bros, the studio behind the film, has defended it saying "neither the fictional character Joker, nor the film, is an endorsement of real-world violence of any kind".

The film, rated a 15 in the UK for "strong bloody violence", also features Robert De Niro, Zazie Beetz and Frances Conroy in supporting roles.

The Joker opened in UK theatres on Friday.
description: Joaquin Phoenix stars in the recently-released film which has hit the headlines due to its intense level of violence
